ai_content: BREAKING NEWS: CDC Warns Pet Owners of COVID-19 Transmission from Animals The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued an interim guidance for pet owners to be cautious about possible COVID-19 transmission from their furry companions. According to the CDC, there have been several cases of pets and other animals, including service or working animals, testing positive for COVID-19 after being exposed to the virus by their owners. The agency recommends that pet owners who have COVID-19 should avoid contact with their animals and have someone else take care of them until they are no longer contagious. The agency also recommends that pets be kept indoors and away from other animals and people outside the household. While the risk of transmission from animals to humans is low, the CDC warns that it is still possible and that precautions should be taken to protect both pets and their owners. The agency is continuing to monitor the situation and provide updates as new information becomes available.

The study, which was conducted by a team of scientists from around the world, analyzed data from over 10,000 people who contracted the virus. However, it also means that people need to be more vigilant than ever, and take every precaution to prevent the spread of the virus.
